archdesc.runner: Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University

did.head: Descriptive Summary
did.repository: Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.
did.abstract: The John Janney Papers consist of over 800 letters written to John Janney and members of his family. Other materials include biographical information, books, and periodicals.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Permission to publish from the John Janney Papers must be obtained from Special Collections, Virginia Tech.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: John Janney Papers, Ms2001-019, Special Collections, Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, Blacksburg, Va.

acqinfo.head: Acquisition Information
acqinfo.p: The John Janney Papers were donated to Special Collections in 2000.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: The processing, arrangement, and description of the John Janney Papers commenced and was completed in 2001.

bioghist.head: Biographical Information
bioghist.p: On November 8, 1798, John Janney was born in Alexandria, Virginia, to Elisha and Mary Janney. The Janneys were members of the religious denomination of Friends or Quakers. Janney obtained little formal education, instead going to work at his father's mill. He later left the mill to study law, and at the age of eighteen, he entered the Bar in Loudoun County. On January 26, 1826, Janney married Alcinda (Alice) Marmaduke. When separated, they wrote almost daily letters to one another.

Janney became a respected lawyer and in 1850 he represented Loudoun County at the Virginia Constitutional Convention. Janney also served his state when he accepted the position as President of the Virginia Secession Convention in 1861. As a strong Whig and Unionist, Janney fought against secession and voted against it twice. When secession finally passed, Janney embraced it fully. He signed the Ordinance of Secession and formally appointed Robert E. Lee as commander of military forces of Virginia. Janney continued to serve as a lawyer in Loudoun until his death in 1872.

Charles Janney, nephew of John Janney, was born May 27, 1839 to James and Rebecca Janney. Charles Janney attended the Benjamin Hallowell School in Alexandria, Virginia until his eighteenth birthday. After graduation, Janney worked at his father's flour mill while also studying the law. Janney ran for office and was elected clerk of the county court for Loudoun and served in that position until he entered the Bar in 1871. In 1921, he was elected as mayor of Leesburg and served for two years.
Charles Janney married Nannie Lee Pollock on November 23, 1868. They had eight children: Thomas, Rebecca, Lilas, Charles P., A.D. Pollock, Phillip, Nannie, and John.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The John Janney Papers consist of over 800 letters written to John Janney and members of his family. The most influential letters are ones written between John Janney and his wife while Janney served as President of the Virginia Secession Convention. In these letters Janney gives brief details of the Convention and comments on the other delegates in attendance. Other letters are between Charles Janney and his wife and family. The bulk of the letters describe legal matters and are from John Janney's years as a practicing lawyer. Additional materials include biographical information, books, and periodicals.
Images from this collection are available on Imagebase.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is arranged into three series:

Series I: Biographical Information is arranged in four subseries: John Janney, Charles Janney, Journal of the Convention, and Miscellaneous Government Documents. This series includes biographical information, newspapers, inventory of property, and Convention minutes. Each subseries is arranged chronologically.

Series II: Correspondence is arranged in ten subseries: John Janney with Alice Janney (wife); Alice Janney with John Janney; Janney Family Letters; Letters to Alice Janney; Pollock Family Papers; Charles Janney Papers; John Janney Letters; John Janney Legal Letters and Court Cases; Court Cases; and Miscallenous Letters.
Series III: Books, Periodicals, and Media is arranged in three subseries: Books, Periodicals, and Media.

did.unittitle: Speech given by Wilbur C. Hall, Chairman of the VA Conservation Commission to the Rotary Club. Contains 27 page biography including acceptance speech to Robert E. Lee.
Loudoun County and the Civil War. 3 page entry on the life of John Janney.
Virginia Magazine of History and Biography, Vol. 102, No. 3. Short, incomplete biography, July 1994.
Passages from Virginia's Attitude Toward Slavery and Secession, by Beverley Mumford, Oct 1909. Janney's acceptance speech to the Secession Convention, 1909.
Speech by Janney to the Secession Convention.
Janney's discussion with Robert E. Lee before and after Gettysburg.
Biographical Register of Members, Virginia State Convention of 1861. 1 page biography of Janney, by the VA State Library, 1969.
Speech from Janney to Lee, charging Lee with command of military forces in Virginia and Lee's response, April 23, 1861.
Janney's speech to the Convention accepting the Presidency.
Congressional Record of the House. Janney missed being President of the United States by one vote.
Congressional Record of the House. Janney elected President of the Convention, his acceptance speech, and Charge to Lee to command Virginia's forces.
Journal of the Acts and Proceedings of a General Convention of the State of Virginia.
Unfinished history of Janney written by Major John M. Orr, 1890s.
Story of Janney Collection. Janney's nephew married into the Lee Family, Loudoun Times Mirror, August 3, 1967.
Inventory for the sale of Alice Janney's possessions, October 8, 1878.
History and genealogical information of Charles Janney by the American Historical Society, 1922.
Plan proposed to the committee on the judiciary by John Janney, 1850.
Political letter to John Janney from N. Janney from St. Louis—discusses politicts over state banks, hard currency, and Van Buren, 1836.
Letters from Nathaniel Janney to Charles and Nannie Janney, 1868.
Letters from Nathaniel Janney to Charles and Nannie Janney, 1871.
Letters from John B. Janney to Rebecca Janney, 1871.
John B. Janney to his Mother—dealt with the raising of Lee Statue, 1890.
Letters to Phinnas Janney from Henry Miller David.
Letters from Lizzy (Alice Janney's live in girl).
Letters to Alice Janney, dealing with the sickness and death of John Janney, 1871-1878, n.d.
